title: Savory Cheese & Cottage Cheese Flatbread (Pan-Cooked)
description: A single-pan savory flatbread made with cottage cheese, grated hard cheese and green onion. Designed for reproducible execution by a cooking robot: precise weights/volumes, defined equipment, explicit actions, sensor checks and exact timings/temperatures. Yields one 22–24 cm flatbread suitable for 3–4 servings.

ingredients.name: green onion (scallion), trimmed
ingredients.notes: about ⅓ cup chopped; see prep for cut size

ingredients.name: cottage cheese (drained)
ingredients.notes: small-curd or regular; drain excess whey if very wet

ingredients.name: grated hard cheese
ingredients.notes: e.g., Parmesan or other hard cheese, finely grated

ingredients.name: sunflower oil (or olive oil)
ingredients.notes: 1 tablespoon; enough to create a thin coating on the pan

equipment.name: precision scale
equipment.purpose: weigh solids and liquids to grams

equipment.name: measuring cylinder or graduated cup
equipment.purpose: measure 100 ml milk and 15 ml oil if scale not used

equipment.name: chef's knife (robot-compatible) or vegetable chopper
equipment.purpose: dice green onion to 3–5 mm pieces

equipment.name: spatula
equipment.purpose: mixing and spreading batter in pan

equipment.name: induction or gas cooktop with temperature control or surface thermometer
equipment.purpose: set and monitor pan surface temperature

equipment.name: heatproof plate or cutting board (for flipping)
paper towel or thin lint-free cloth
equipment.purpose: spread oil into a thin film

safety: Use heat sensors and thermal cutouts. Maintain protective distance when flipping with plate.
Handle hot surfaces with robot gripper rated for expected temperatures.
Ensure eggs are fresh (use standard freshness check).
assumptions: Robot has access to a flat-bottom non-stick pan and can control cooktop to target surface temperatures.
Robot can perform basic knife/food manipulations and can handle plates/cutting boards for flipping.
Visual inspection or simple motion-detection is available to verify 'jiggle' and surface color changes.

steps.title: Prepare ingredients and workspace
instruction: Verify ingredient quantities by weighing each ingredient with the precision scale to the gram values listed in the 'ingredients' section.
Bring eggs and milk to room temperature if stored cold (remove from fridge 15–30 minutes before start).
Place pan, lid, spatula, plate/cutting board and paper towel within robot reach.
steps.expected_results: All ingredients measured and laid out; pan and tools ready.

steps.title: Chop green onion
instruction: Trim root ends and any wilted tops from green onions.
Dice green onion into uniform pieces approximately 3–5 mm (0.12–0.20 in).
Weigh 30 g of chopped green onion and set aside.
steps.sensors: vision to verify approximate uniform dice size; scale to confirm weight.
steps.expected_results: 30 g of 3–5 mm diced green onion in a small container.

steps.title: Combine liquid ingredients
instruction: Crack 2 eggs into a small bowl. Whisk eggs until homogeneous.
Add 100 ml room-temperature milk to the whisked eggs. Whisk to combine.
steps.expected_results: Uniform egg-milk mixture, no streaks of egg white or yolk.

steps.title: Assemble batter
instruction: In the large mixing bowl, add in order: 250 g drained cottage cheese, 200 g grated hard cheese, 90 g sifted all-purpose flour, 0.25 tsp (≈1.5 g) salt, and the 30 g diced green onion.
Pour the egg-milk mixture into the bowl.

Mix with a spatula or low-speed mixer until a uniform batter is formed. Mix until there are no visible dry pockets of flour; total mixing time ~30–45 seconds. Aim for a spreadable batter with small cheese curds and no large lumps.
quality_checks: Visually verify there are no dry flour streaks.
Batter viscosity target: should flow slowly when tilted (~1–2 cm/sec edge spread in a 22 cm pan).
steps.expected_results: Evenly mixed batter, homogeneous distribution of cheese and green onion.

steps.title: Prepare pan with thin oil film
instruction: Pour 15 ml oil into a small dispenser next to the pan.
Robot places paper towel on pan surface and uses a small controlled motion to spread oil into a uniform thin film covering the entire cooking surface. Target oil film thickness: ≤0.02 mm.
Remove paper towel and discard or place in waste container.
steps.sensors: vision to verify full coverage; weight/dispensed volume check to confirm ~15 ml used.
steps.expected_results: Pan surface uniformly coated with a thin oil film.

steps.title: Preheat pan to target surface temperature
instruction: Set cooktop/pan surface to 160 °C (320 °F) surface temperature. If only 'medium' power is available, use calibrated medium that reaches 150–170 °C surface. Use a surface thermometer or contact thermocouple to verify.
Wait until pan surface temperature reaches 160 °C ± 10 °C.
steps.sensors: contact surface thermometer reading; only proceed when temperature in range.

steps.title: Pour batter and initial cook
instruction: Pour the batter into the center of the preheated pan. Using the spatula, rapidly spread the batter to an even layer of approximately 22–24 cm diameter and 10–12 mm thickness.
Cover pan with lid immediately.
Cook undisturbed at 160 °C surface for 7 minutes.
sensors_checks: After 5 minutes, use vision to check edge color: edge should begin to brown. If browning is earlier than 6 minutes (edge color L* drop observed), note time and proceed to step 8 when top is set.
At 7 minutes, check top surface for color change to pale yellow and verify that edges have visibly browned.
steps.expected_results: Bottom/edge browned; top mostly set but not fully cooked.

steps.title: Check release/jiggle
instruction: Gently rock the pan (robotically) side to side over a 5 mm amplitude to detect movement of the flatbread.
If the flatbread moves and shows uniform slight jiggle, it is ready to flip. If it sticks, carefully loosen edges with a thin spatula and re-check.
steps.sensors: force/torque sensors on pan holder to detect movement; vision to observe edge separation.
decision: If detectable release achieved → proceed to flip (step 9).
If still sticking after gentle loosening → continue cooking covered at 160 °C for additional 1 minute, then re-check (repeat up to twice).
steps.expected_results: Flatbread moves freely in pan with minimal sticking.

steps.title: Flip flatbread using plate
instruction: Select a heatproof plate or cutting board with diameter equal to or slightly larger than the flatbread (22–26 cm). Place the plate centered on top of the pan.
Secure plate with robot gripper and invert pan+plate assembly so the cooked side transfers to the plate. Perform inversion in a single smooth motion to minimize deformation.
Quickly but carefully slide the flatbread (cooked side up) from the plate back into the pan to place uncooked side down. Use a spatula to assist alignment if necessary.
Warning: plate and pan surfaces will be hot. Use thermal-rated grippers and maintain safe acceleration to prevent spills.
steps.sensors: vision to confirm full transfer; temperature sensors to ensure grip safety.
steps.expected_results: Flatbread successfully flipped; uncooked side now contacting pan surface.

steps.title: Finish cook on low heat
instruction: Reduce cooktop/pan surface to low: target 100–120 °C surface temperature.
Cover with lid and cook for 6 minutes (target: 5–7 minutes) at 100–120 °C until the second side is set and lightly browned.
After 6 minutes, remove lid and visually inspect top for uniform set and light golden color.
steps.expected_results: Both sides cooked through; internal temperature reaches at least 75 °C in center when probed.

steps.title: Remove and rest
instruction: Place a cutting board or plate on top of the pan and invert again to transfer the flatbread onto the board (cooked side up).
Allow the flatbread to rest for 2 minutes on the board to stabilize structure before cutting and serving.
steps.sensors: vision to confirm intact transfer; thermometer to verify cooling to safe handling temperature ~60–65 °C if immediate cutting required.
steps.expected_results: Flatbread on board, intact and ready to portion.

steps.title: Portion and serve
instruction: Cut the flatbread into 6 equal wedges using a chef's knife. Wipe blade between cuts for clean edges.
Serve warm or at room temperature. Optional: garnish with extra chopped green onion or a dollop of sour cream.
steps.expected_results: 6 uniform portions; internal texture is soft with integrated cheese and green onion pieces.

visual_checks: Edge browning after initial cook (brown color visible around circumference).
Top surface changes to pale yellow and loses glossy wet appearance before flip.
After finish cook, top is uniformly set and lightly golden.
mechanical_checks: Pan-rock test: flatbread moves/jiggles when pan is shaken → indicates release.
Spatula loosening if sticking is detected.

storage.short_term: Store covered in refrigerator up to 3 days. Reheat in pan at low heat until warmed through (avoid drying).
storage.freezing: Not recommended for best texture; can freeze portions wrapped airtight up to 1 month and thaw overnight in refrigerator before reheating.

possible_causes: Pan not properly oiled or oil burned
Pan temperature too high causing proteins to bond to surface
solutions: Ensure a thin oil film is applied before heating (step 5).
Lower initial surface temperature by 10–20 °C and increase initial cook time by 1 minute.
Loosen edges with thin spatula and wait 30–60 seconds; then retry pan-rock test.

possible_causes: Layer too thick (>12 mm) or pan temperature too low
solutions: Spread batter thinner to 10–12 mm thickness.
Ensure eggs and milk are at room temperature before mixing.
After flipping, increase low-heat finish time by 1–2 minutes and confirm internal temperature ≥75 °C.

notes.original_author_note: A savory, rich flavor of cottage cheese and cheese. The green onion only slightly complements the flavor; preferred for breakfast but good any time of day. In the original project, the dish was prepared by the author's 9-year-old daughter.
notes.video_reference: Original video demonstration available (Russian) at https://youtu.be/f44GWPEu8us— timing reference for the flip is ~7:32 in the video.
robotization_tips: Use a non-stick pan with a slight lip for safe inversion during robotic flip.
Calibrate 'medium' and 'low' cooktop settings against pan surface thermometer before first production run.
